Resource.DescriptionText:
"The AWWA Free Water Audit SoftwareÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â© (Audit Software) was first released in 2006, and has been through several generations. It includes a data-grading capability that allows the auditor to rate the overall degree of validity of their water audit data. Guidance on loss control planning is given based upon the credibility of the data and the measure of losses displayed by the water audit. The current version of the Audit Software is Version 5.0, published in 2014. Highlighted features of Version 5.0 include a visual dashboard for graphical display of nonrevenue water components, a comments feature for capture of essential notes, and improved overall user experience.
The AWWA Water Audit CompilerÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â© (Compiler) was launched in 2011 and can be utilized to quickly assemble water audit data from multiple water utilities; allowing for comparisons of data across water utilities.
The Leakage Component Analysis (LCA) Model was developed to provide the water industry with a computer-based model for leakage component analysis, failure frequency analysis, economic leakage control intervention strategy evaluation, and display of key water loss performance indicators. "
Resource.CommentsText: A complete water loss toolset. This is a good staring point for utilities large or small. Will require training via online tutorials. If the system has an Asset Management system in placed it may already have a water loss component.

Resource.PrimaryOrganizationText: EPA / OEI / OIC / IESD - Information Exchange and Services Division
Resource.DescriptionText: EPA's Benchmark Dose Software (BMDS) fits mathematical models to doe-response or exposure-response data. This software can help EPA risk assessors estimate the dose or exposure of a chemical or chemical mixture, with confidence limits, that is associated with a given response level. This dose or exposure estimate can be used as a benchmark for establishing guidelines that help protect against the adverse health effects associated with the chemical or chemical mixture.
Resource.CommentsText: Advanced tool to determine mathematical models on exposure data.
Resource.TopicText: Brownfields and Re-development and Industrial Cleanup

Resource.ResourceName: Better Assessment Science Integrating Point and Nonpoint Sources (BASINS)

Resource.DescriptionText: Building Blocks for Sustainable Communities provides quick, targeted technical assistance to selected communities using a variety of tools that have demonstrated results and widespread application. The purpose of delivering these tools is to stimulate a discussion about growth and development and strengthen local capacity to implement sustainable approaches.
Resource.CommentsText: Provides a series of different tools or information regarding how to build and develop a sustainable community.

Resource.DescriptionText: Search and find Business Funding sources and solutions. Fill out the questionnaire, show how many funding sources match, review matches. This service provides businesses with a resource to see available funding for specific topics.

Resource.ResourceName: Catalog of Federal Funding Sources for Watershed Protection
Resource.DescriptionText: The Catalog of Federal Funding Sources for Watershed Protection Web site is a searchable database of financial assistance sources (grants, loans, cost-sharing) available to fund a variety of watershed protection projects. To select funding programs for particular requirements, use the search below. You can use subject matter criteria based searches, or general word based searches of the funding programs, or both. Criteria searches include the type of organization (e.g., non-profit groups, private landowner, state, business), type of assistance sought (grants or loans), and keywords (e.g., agriculture, wildlife habitat).
Resource.CommentsText: Easy to use and search based on predefined set criteria.

Resource.ResourceName: Check up program for small systems
Resource.CommentsText: A complete asset management system for small utilities, include inventory, O&M and finance forms to collect and report data in developing an AMP. The toolset includes training, the system and technical assistance. Updated annually and has been used by 1000s of utilities. Has been integrated into several state utility trainings.

Resource.ResourceName: Clean Power Plan Toolbox for States
Resource.DescriptionText: As co-regulators, states will develop plans to meet the guidelines in theÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â Clean Power Plan (CPP). The federalÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â resources provide information on state plan development and can help states determine the most cost-effective approaches to reducing greenhouse gas emissions from the power sector. Please note that inclusion of a measure in the toolbox does not mean that a state plan must include that measure. In addition, inclusion of these measures does not necessarily imply the approvability of an approach or method for use in a state plan. States will need to demonstrate that any measure included in a state plan meets all relevant criteria and adequately addresses elements of the plan components.ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â Please check this page for frequent updates. ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â
Resource.CommentsText: Help states to determine most cost-effective approach to reducing greenhouse gas emissions from the power sector.

Resource.DescriptionText: This Climate and Disaster Risk Screening Tool provides a systematic way to undertake due diligence and flag potential risks for projects in the General sector. The tool guides the user through a simple step-by-step approach to identifying potential risks at an early stage of project design. Users can browse the tool by creating their own log-in username and password.

"This risk assessment tool allows water utilities to evaluate potential impacts of climate change. You can also identify adaptation options to address impacts using both traditional risk assessment and scenario-based methods. CREAT provides: ÃƒÂ¢Ã‚Â€Ã‚Â¢Lists of drinking water and wastewater utility assets (such as water resources, treatment plants, and pump stations) that climate change could impact ÃƒÂ¢Ã‚Â€Ã‚Â¢Possible climate change-related threats (such as flooding, drought, and water quality) ÃƒÂ¢Ã‚Â€Ã‚Â¢Adaptive measures that utilities can implement to reduce potential impacts "
Resource.CommentsText: Good starting tool for testing impact of climate change scenarios. Nothing as comprehensive as HAZUS but a good tool for small utilities. Is updated and maintained by Water Security Division.

Resource.DescriptionText: 3. Explore potential opportunities for reducing short-lived climate pollutants (SLCPs) emissions from the municipal solid waste sector
Resource.CommentsText: The self-assessmentÃ‚Â in the tool is for: Drinking water and wastewater utilities, state primacy agencies, hospitals, public health agencies, fire, police, emergency managers, elected officials, concerned citizens.

Resource.ResourceName: Cost Evaluation of Point-of-Use and Point-of-Entry Treatment Units for Small Systems: Cost Estimating Tool and Users Guide
Resource.DescriptionText: A companion tool to the Treatment Options Guide for modeling operations and maintenance (e.g., maintenance, monitoring, and public education) and capital costs (e.g., purchase, installation, and permitting).
Resource.CommentsText: Very focused on one treatment technology.

Resource.ResourceName: Data Collection Tool for Urban Solid Waste Management
Resource.DescriptionText: The purpose of this tool is to collect municipal solid waste data in a consistent manner to serve the following purposes: Facilitate the development of municipal solid waste master plans for cities, facilitate the preparation and implementation of investment projects, including those using Result-based financing (RBF) approaches, and exploring the potential for reducing short-lived climate pollutants(SLCP) emissions from the municipal solid waste sector.
Resource.CommentsText: Download excel document.

Resource.ResourceName: Discharge Monitoring Report (DMR) Pollutant Loading Tool
Resource.DescriptionText: The Discharge Monitoring Report (DMR) Pollutant Loading Tool is designed to help you determineÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â who is discharging, what pollutants they are discharging and how much, and where they are discharging. The tool calculates pollutant loadings from permit and DMR data from EPA's Integrated Compliance Information System for the National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (ICIS-NPDES).ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â
Resource.CommentsText: Beneficial tool for discharge monitoring.

Resource.DescriptionText: The Water Research Foundation has developed a tool to help water and wastewater utilities evaluate their current and desired levels of performance related to the 10 attributes that were identified in the EPA report, Effective Utility Management: A Primer for Water and Wastewater Utilities (2008). The tool is aligned with the Primer, identifies practice areas used by the water sector to support each attribute, and provides a structured process benchmarking exercise to help water utilities conduct a self-assessment of any or all of the 10 attributes that they want to improve to meet their goals.
Resource.CommentsText: Good tool for KPI, especially for utilities that are not using an off the shelf Asset Management Tool.

Resource.DescriptionText: To find EPA's current and past emergency response activities in your community, please use ourÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â Cleanups in My CommunityÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â tool. Simply enter your street address or zip code, and click "Map It."
Resource.CommentsText: Map that provides resource location and contact information for emergency management.

Resource.ResourceName: HEC-RAS Hydrologic Engineer Centers River Analysis System
Resource.DescriptionText: Allows user to perform one dimensional steady flow, unsteady flow, sediment transport/mobile bed computations, and water temperature modeling. Specifically designed to support water resources management with water resource planning and management tools. Designed to perform a one-dimensional hydraulic calculations for a full network of natural and constructed channels.

Resource.PrimaryOrganizationText: EPA / OEI / OIC / IESD - Information Exchange and Services Division
Resource.DescriptionText: Use models and tools developed or supported by NREL to assess, analyze, and optimize renewable energy and energy efficiency technologies for your project. Many of these tools can be applied on a global, regional, local, or project basis. NREL models and tools include several designed for the consumer or energy professional.
Resource.CommentsText:
Variety of tools to use for data analysis on a variety of renewable energy options. Tools vary in difficulty and use.
This tool is already catalogued in RCS as an External Developer Resource. However, this records should contain better metadata and we plan to delete the other one.

Resource.DescriptionText: Desktop application that estimates the annual amount of rainwater and frequency of runoff from a specific site anywhere in the United States (including Puerto Rico). Estimates are based on local soil conditions, land cover, and historic rainfall records. Designed to be used by anyone interested in reducing runoff from a property including site developers, landscape architects, urban planners, and homeowners.
Resource.CommentsText: Website provides training materials and information on the application. Calculator accesses several national databases that provide soil, topography, rainfall, and evaporation information for the chosen site.

Resource.ResourceName: Open Data: U.S. Energy Information Administration
Resource.DescriptionText: The U.S. Energy Information Administration is committed to enhancing the value of its free and open data by making it available through an Application Programming Interface (API) and open data tools to better serve our customers. The data in the API is also available in bulk file, in Excel via the add-in, and via widgets that embed interactive data vizualizations of EIA data on any website. By making EIA data available in machine-readable formats, the creativity in the private, the non-profit, and the public sectors can be harnessed to find new ways to innovate and create value-added services powered by public data.
Resource.CommentsText: API provided for a series of different data sets regarding energy consumption.

Resource.DescriptionText: Program for predicating polluting particle passage through pits, puddles and ponds. This model predicts the generation and transport of stormwater runoff pollutants in urban watersheds. Continuous water-balance and mass-balance calculations are performed on a user-defined system consisting of the following elements: watersheds; devices; particle classes; water quality components.
Resource.CommentsText: May have compatibility issues.

Resource.PrimaryOrganizationText: EPA / OEI / OIC / IESD - Information Exchange and Services Division
Resource.DescriptionText: "The purpose of this tool is to prioritize your water distribution and transmission pipes for renewal projects. This prioritization will identify the set of pipes most at risk for failure and with the greatest cost-based consequences for inclusion in your capital improvement program (CIP). "
Resource.CommentsText: Good tool for CIP, especially for utilities that are not using an off the shelf Asset Management Tool.

Resource.ResourceName: Renewable Energy Ready Home Solar Site Assessment Tool
Resource.DescriptionText: The Renewable Energy Ready Home Solar Site Assessment Tool is intended to guide home builders in assessing whether a new home has the proper physical orientation to support a future installation of a solar energy system. This tool evaluates the proposed site's solar resource potential based on a series of known factors about the home at the time of construction, such as the home's location and anticipated shading effects at the proposed site. New homes that are found to provide a suitable installation environment are considered good candidates to be outfitted by the builder with the structural and system components needed to support the cost effective installation of a future renewable energy system.
Resource.CommentsText: Assessment tool provides basic information relating to your location and roof angles on solar energy capacity.

Resource.DescriptionText:
"Water Utility Response On-The-Go is an innovative tool that consolidates information and tools that water utility operators and their response partners may need during an emergency. The tool is ideal for small systems that lack a large support network in place when natural disasters strike. Water Utility Response On-The-Go allows users to accomplish the following:
identify and contact emergency response partners monitor local and national severe weather conditions review and complete incident-specific checklists; and populate save and email both generic damage assessment forms and FEMA incident command system form"
Resource.CommentsText: New tool for mobile Emergency Preparedness. Great tool to help utilities ready for emergency situations and help meet water security requirements. This tool could be moved to the Emergency Management category as well.

Resource.ResourceName: Sanitary Sewer Overflow Analysis and Planning (SSOAP) Toolbox
Resource.DescriptionText: Rainfall-derived infiltration and inflow (RDII) is the increased portion water flow in a sanitary sewer system that occurs during and after a rainfall as a source of operating problems in sanitary sewer systems. SSOAP toolbox is a suite of computer software tools used for the quantification of RDII and help capacity analysis and condition assessment of sanitary sewer systems. This toolbox includes the previous SWMM-5 for performing dynamic routing of flows through the sanitary sewer systems. Prediction methodology employed in the SSOAP toolbox offers an effective means to design a focused sewer condition assessment program and maximize success of field investigation efforts.
Resource.CommentsText: Determines RDII characteristics, prioritizes sewer sheds for sewer condition assessment, sewer rehabilitation, evaluates performance of sewer improvements, managing and analyzing flow monitoring and rainfall data.

Resource.ResourceName: Security and Emergency Response Planning Toolbox for Small Water and Wastewater Systems
Resource.CommentsText: Good tool for utilities to run table top exercise. Maybe better as a web tool to allow sharing of results. Older tool and more focused on training. EPA Water Security tools seem to be better and more available/newer. This tool is very small system focused.

Resource.DescriptionText: Allow citizens to connect with government. App allows local citizens to report possible disasters in order to get issues addressed quickly. Provides a series of reporting tools that are beneficial for analysis or potential problem areas. App connects governments and citizens in a quick and efficient fashion.
Resource.CommentsText: Reporting tool based on application to connect citizens with local government.

Resource.DescriptionText: SolarRating Online uses information collected from over 1000 weather stations worldwide to assess the suitability of your home for solar technologies: photovoltaic (PV) to generate electricity and solar thermal for heating domestic hot water.
Resource.CommentsText: Assessment tool provides basic information relating to your location and roof angles on solar energy capacity.

Resource.ResourceName: Source Water Protection Cost Benefit Analysis Tool
Resource.DescriptionText: This tool is designed to assist you in evaluating the triple bottom-line costs and benefits of different source water protection options. Cost/benefit calculations help evaluate, prioritize, justify, and ultimately implement source water protection initiatives.
Resource.CommentsText: Although a useful tool not many small utilities conduct triple bottom line analysis on source water. But it is simple to use and relatively straightforward for most audience.

Resource.DescriptionText: Used throughout world for planning, analysis and design related to Stormwater runoff, combined and sanitary sewers, and other drainage systems in urban areas. There are many applications for drainage systems in non-urban areas as well. Dynamic hydrology-hydraulic water quality simulation model. Used for single event or long-term simulation of runoff quantity and quality from primarily urban areas.
Resource.CommentsText: SWMM Climate Adjustment Tool allows future climate change projections to be incorporated into the Stormwater management model.

Resource.DescriptionText: Using Surf Your Watershed, a watershed can be quickly located. Once located, simply click on the first link, ÃƒÂƒÃ‚Â¢ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â€ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Âœcitizen-based groups at work in this watershedÃƒÂƒÃ‚Â¢ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â€ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â, to find a listing of organizations that are working to protect water quality. Discover cleanups, monitoring activities, restoration projects, and other activities by contacting those organizations.
Resource.CommentsText: After a basic search, provides a list of entities that are working to protect the searched watershed. Provides contact information as well as other basic links to click for more information.

Resource.ResourceName: System for Urban Stormwater Treatment and Analysis Integration(SUSTAIN)
Resource.DescriptionText: A decision support system that assists stormwater management professionals with developing and implementing plans for flow and pollution control measures to protect source waters and meet water quality goals. SUSTAIN allows watershed and stormwater practitioners to develop, evaluate, and select optimal best management practice (BMP) combinations at various watershed scales based on cost and effectiveness.

Resource.ResourceName: Tabletop Exercise Tool for Water Systems (TTX Tool)
Resource.DescriptionText:
"The PC-based Tabletop Exercise Tool for Water Systems: Emergency Preparedness, Response, and Climate Resiliency (TTX Tool) contains materials that assist those interested in planning and facilitating tabletop exercises that focus on Water Sector-related issues.
This updated TTX Tool contains 15 scenarios that address an all-hazards approach to emergency preparedness and response. It addresses natural hazards and man-made incidents and introduces the potential impacts of climate change on the water sector. "
Resource.CommentsText: Good tool for utilities to run table top exercise. Maybe better as a web tool to allow sharing of results. Older tool.

Resource.DescriptionText: Sustainable design to assit tribal communities to reduce the impact of construction on the environment while protecting the health, livelihood and the culture of tribal residents. The toolkit is designed to help tribal officials, community members, planners, developers, and architects develop and adopt building codes to support green building practices.
Resource.CommentsText: Easy to use toolkit to help in the sustainable development of tribal communities.

Resource.DescriptionText: VSAT Version 6.0 complies with the water sector risk assessment standard and can offer liability protection under the Department of Homeland SecurityÃ¢Â€Â™s Support Anti-Terrorism by Fostering Effective Technologies (SAFETY) Act program. EPA strongly encourages drinkingÃ‚Â water and wastewater utility owners and operators to use VSAT 6.0 to conduct or update an all-hazards risk assessment.

Resource.ResourceName: WAWTTAR (Water and Wastewater Treatment Technologies Appropriate for Reuse).
Resource.DescriptionText: WAWTTAR is a predictive program intended to assist planners in selecting suitable water and wastewater treatment options appropriate to the material and manpower resources available to particular communities throughout the world. WAWTTAR is designed to assist in alleviating the problem of overlooking good processes alternatives for water and wastewater treatment, and also help screen out treatment technologies which are inappropriate for given locales and situations.
Resource.CommentsText: This would be a better tool if it was updated more frequently. Treatment options tools seem to be limited.

Resource.ResourceName: WEPPCAT: Online Tool for Assessing and Managing the Potential Impacts of Climate Change on Sediment Loading to Streams Using the Water Erosion Prediction Project (WEPP) Model.
Resource.DescriptionText: WEPPCAT is an on-line tool that provides a flexible capability for creating user-determined climate change scenarios for assessing the potential impacts of climate change on sediment loading to streams using the USDAÃ¢Â€Â™s Water Erosion Prediction Project (WEPP) Model. In combination with the existing capabilities of WEPP for assessing the effectiveness of management practices, WEPPCAT also can be used to evaluate the effectiveness of strategies for managing the impacts of climate change.Ã‚Â

Resource.PrimaryOrganizationText: EPA / OEI / OIC / IESD - Information Exchange and Services Division
Resource.DescriptionText: This calculator provides the user with a series of questions regarding soil, air, or tap water readings. It will require the user to have specific chemical data regarding these topics. The user will select a list of individual chemicals as well as their levels. The calculator will then provide the safe amount for all age levels.
Resource.CommentsText: User will need to have specific chemical information in order to retrieve active results. However, you are able to do a generic search of specific chemicals to see their levels of safety.
Resource.TopicText: Brownfields and Re-development and Industrial Cleanup

Resource.ResourceName: Water Utility Customer Assistance Program Cost Estimation Tool
Resource.DescriptionText: This tool was developed to help utilities assess the costs and benefits of implementing a customer affordability program in their service area. Using information from the U.S. Census Bureau and water and wastewater rates inputted by the user, this interactive instrument incorporates information about the eligibility threshold to qualify for an affordability program, annual assistance offered per customer, percent of customers responsible for bad debt, among other fields.
Resource.CommentsText: Good tool for setting up rate programs for rural or low income areas. Simple to use.

Resource.DescriptionText: The tool is designed for users who are involved in watershed management activities. These activities include the development and implementation of watershed plans, the analysis of data and the implementation of management practices.
Resource.CommentsText: Application can be used to plan and analyze watersheds. Allows for user to save and load previous plans. Powered by ESRI.

Resource.DescriptionText: TheÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â Climate Change, Wildlife and Wildlands Toolkit for Formal and Informal EducatorsÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â is an updated and expanded version of the award-winning and very popularÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â Climate Change, Wildlife and Wildlands Toolkit for Teachers and Interpreters,ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â which was first published in 2001. The kit is designed for classroom teachers and informal educators in parks, refuges, forest lands, nature centers, zoos, aquariums, science centers, etc., and is aimed at the middle school grade level.
Resource.CommentsText: Highly recommended for students.

Resource.DescriptionText: The DataFinder is an app for accessing data on global development indicators from The World Bank Group.ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â
Resource.CommentsText: Police

Resource.PrimaryOrganizationText: EPA / OEI / OIC / IESD - Information Exchange and Services Division
Resource.DescriptionText: Map out your customizable project and receive basic capacity, energy yield, revenue and system displacement data. Map site, plot site, configure set, and analyze the site data. The tool provides a basic tool as well as an advanced tool. Each tool requires the user to log in.
Resource.CommentsText: Tool provides a great deal of information on the possibility of using solar for particular locations. Tool allows the use to select locations.

Resource.DescriptionText: Data related to climate change that can help inform and prepare America's communities, businesses, and citizens. You can currently find data and resources related to costal flooding, food resilience, water, ecosystem vulnerabilitym human health, energy infrastructurem transportation and the artic region. Over time you will be able to find additional data and tools relevant to other important climate-related impacts.
Resource.CommentsText: Data base search with a map to help narrow search results for Climate Change.

Resource.DescriptionText: Know your H20 is a free application available on the iTunes and Android App stores. Know Your H2O? helps you to identify the existing and historic environmental hazards in your community. They are working with a national environmental database search company to offer a report to help you understand your homeÃƒÂ¢Ã‚Â€Ã‚Â™s or your future homes environmental health status within a community. They are doing this by taking a snapshot of the current and historic environmental concerns and hazards in the community and a review of select criminal activity.
Resource.CommentsText: Application is free. Requires a smart phone. Know Your H2O? is an educational tool that can help you diagnose the problem with your water. This app will lead you through a series of questions to pinpoint the issues with your water. You can reach your diagnosis through describing symptoms that are effecting your home, your health, or the water itself. Once you receive your diagnosis result(s), the app is designed to educate you by displaying full lists of symptoms, causes, and solutions, as well as links to other educational sources. The app will then show you various testing kit options specifically designed to treat those results. If the problem is more extensive and in depth testing is required, Know Your H2O? will also connect you with featured local professionals.

Resource.DescriptionText: "A simple form builder for mobile devices to allow users to manage and create forms for inspections and other utility data collection. "
Resource.CommentsText: Only include as an example of a free mobile form builder that utilities could use to build inspection or O&M forms. This can be used by utilities to build forms or websites. We can include more of these technologies if this seems relevant.

Resource.DescriptionText: Apple App for mobile devices. This application is ideal for Users of all ages where they can learn about water quality parameters such as Dissolved Oxygen, E. coli, pH, Nutrients, Turbidity and much more. Students can gather data about their field study site in a site profile. The Benthic Macro invertebrates section acts as a field guide of all of the major taxa used to calculate pollution tolerance indexes. Pictures, sketches and descriptions for identification are included for twenty-two macro invertebrates. Scientists and citizen science groups can use the Water Quality app to learn about water quality parameters and to collect chemical and biological data from their study sites. Data are organized in reports and can be printed or submitted to the River on the Web database.
Resource.CommentsText: This application is a pay to use application. It costs $4.99 on the iTunes Application store.

Resource.DescriptionText: Software that models the hydraulic and water quality behaviors of water distribution piping systems. Performs extended period simulation of water movement and quality behavior within pressurized pipe networks. EPANET tracks the flow of water in each pipe, the pressure at each node, the height of the water in each tank, the type of chemical concentration throughout the network during a simulation period, water age, source, and tracking.

Resource.ResourceName: EPAS Composite Model for Leachate Migration with Transformation Products
Resource.PrimaryOrganizationText: EPA / OLEM - Office of Land and Emergency Management
Resource.DescriptionText: EPACMTP (EPA's Composite Model for Leachate Migration with Transformation Products) version 2.0 is a subsurface fate and transport model used by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to simulate the impact of the release of constituents present in waste that is managed in land-based waste mangement units. EPACMTP simulates fate and transport in both the unsaturated zone and the saturated zone (ground water) using the advective-dispersive equation with terms to account for equilibrium sorption and first-order transformation. The Model simulates the migration of a chemical constituent vertically downward from the base of a waste management unit through the unsaturated zone until it reachs the water table. As the leachate enters the ground water, it will mix with ambient ground water (which is assumed to be free of pollutants) and a contaminant plume, which extends in the direction of downgradient ground-water flow, will develop. EPACMTP accounts for the spreading of the plume in
Resource.CommentsText: .exe file. Requires knowledge, but useful tool.
Resource.SourceSystemText: Registry of EPA Applications and Databases

Resource.PrimaryOrganizationText: EPA / OLEM / ORCR / MISWD - Municipal and Industrial Solid Waste Division
Resource.DescriptionText: The IWAIR model was developed by EPA for use in evaluating inhalation risks. Using limited site-specific information, IWAIR can estimate whether specific wastes and management practices may pose an unacceptable risk to human health. IWAIR consists of three components: an emissions model, a dispersion model to determine ambient air concentrations at specified receptor locations; and a risk model to calculate either the risk to exposed individuals or waste constituent concentrations in the waste management unit. This model, along with IWEM, are companion tools associated with The Guide to Industrial Waste Management (EPA530-99-001).
Resource.CommentsText: .exe file. Requires knowledge, but useful tool.
Resource.KeywordsText: OSWER, ORCR, solid waste, industrial waste, non-hazardous
Resource.SourceSystemText: Registry of EPA Applications and Databases

Resource.PrimaryOrganizationText: EPA / OLEM / ORCR / MISWD - Municipal and Industrial Solid Waste Division
Resource.DescriptionText: The IWEM software helps industrial waste facility managers (or beneficial users) determine the most appropriate waste management unit design(or the appropriateness of beneficially reusing industrial materials) by evaluating one or more types of liners, the hydrologic conditions of the site, and the toxicity and expected leachate concentrations of the anticipated waste constituents. This information allows managers to determine minimum liner requirements required to protect ground water or determine whether the beneficial use of industrial materials is appropriate or not.
Resource.CommentsText: .exe file. Requires knowledge, but useful tool.
Resource.KeywordsText: OSWER, OSW, municipal solid waste, waste management, landfil
Resource.SourceSystemText: Registry of EPA Applications and Databases

Resource.DescriptionText: This model helps users interpret and predict water quality responses to natural phenomena and manmade pollution for various pollution management decisions. WASP is a dynamic compartment-modeling program for aquatic systems, including both the water column and the underlying benthos. WASP is one of the most widely used water quality models in the United States. Widely applied in the development of Total Maximum Daily Loads (TMDL). Has capabilities of linking with hydrodynamic and watershed models which allows for multi-year analysis under varying meteorological and environmental conditions.

1. Facilitate the development of municipal solid waste master plans for cities 2. Facilitate the preparation and implementation of investment projects, including those using Result-based financing (RBF) approaches
Resource.CommentsText: Provides a series of workbooks, information, and assessment guidelines depending on the region.
Resource.TopicText: Brownfields and Re-development and Industrial Cleanup

Resource.DescriptionText:
"Building on the success of the original EUM framework, EPA and USDA have developed two new document to help managers of rural and small water and wastewater systems effectively manage their operations. The first document is the Rural and Small Systems Guidebook to Sustainable Utility Management. The Guidebook uses the same EUM framework to help small systems assess their operations and develop a work plan for improving their performance.
Accompanying the Guidebook is the Workshop in a Box which contains materials to help systems and technical assistance providers work with systems using the Guidebook. "
Resource.CommentsText: Primarily guidance and not really a tool. Would be good to have the information available in a tool but on its own it is a guidance document and rather long.

Resource.ResourceName: Industrial Waste Management: A Guide to Best Practices
Resource.PrimaryOrganizationText: EPA / OEI / OIC / IESD - Information Exchange and Services Division
Resource.DescriptionText: EPA has created the Guide for Industrial Waste Management, a one-stop resource for comprehensive and informative tools to help manage industrial waste in your state, company, or community. Available in CDROM, this Guide is the result of a collaborative effort among state and federal regulators, industry, and environmentalists to provide practical information and training on industrial waste management.
Resource.CommentsText: Order form for the waste management guide.

Resource.DescriptionText: The intent of this document is to establish better quality indoor air in the building after construction and during occupancy. conduct baseline IAQ testing using protocols consistent with the methods listed in Table 1 for all occupied spaces. Use current versions of ASTM standard methods, EPA compendium methods, or ISO methods, as indicated.
Resource.CommentsText: LEED certified, or knowledgeable professionals will need to use this tool. Helps assess indoor air quality.

Resource.ResourceName: Mapping Solid Waste: Roadmap for Data Collection
Resource.DescriptionText: Presentation that speaks of the importantce of data collection. Overall roadmap for data collection and the information required before data collection can begin.

Resource.ResourceName: Moving Toward Sustainability: Sustainable and Effective Practices
Resource.DescriptionText: EPA is now issuing Moving Toward Sustainability: Sustainable and Effective Practices for Creating Your Own Water Utility Roadmap. The purposes of this document is to assist utilities move toward sustainability by implementing proven practices over time at a pace consistent with their needs and the needs of the communities they serve. The document includes checklists and recommendations on moving towards sustainability.
Resource.CommentsText: Although a guidance document it is very easy to read and follow and address new topics and ways a small/medium/large utility can move into the 21st century. Great step by step process. Might be an interesting tool that could help work like Equifax or other scoring scenarios to show if you do this your utility can become more sustainable and improve operations and compliance.

Resource.ResourceName: Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) Orientation Manual
Resource.DescriptionText: This manual provides introductory information on the solid and hazardous waste management programs under the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA). Designed for EPA and state staff, members of the regulated community, and the general public who wish to better understand RCRA, this document constitutes a review of the RCRA program and is not a substitute for RCRA or its implementing regulations.
Resource.CommentsText: manual/document for RCRA Orientation.

Resource.ResourceName: Smart Growth Self-Assessment for Rural Communities
Resource.DescriptionText: TheÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â Smart Growth Self-Assessment for Rural CommunitiesÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â (2015) is a compilation of strategies, organized by 11 common "goal areas," that villages, towns, and small cities can use to evaluate their existing policies to create healthy, environmentally resilient, and economically robust places.
Resource.CommentsText: This self-assessment helps communities identify gaps in their policies, plans, codes, and zoning regulations by asking a series of "Yes" or "No" questions. All communities begin by completing the self-assessment's Revitalize Village and Town Centers section, which gives a baseline indication of smart growth development policies within the jurisdiction. It goes beyond regulatory issues to help communities take stock of their local initiatives, strategies, and plans.

Resource.ResourceName: !10 Shocking Facts about Indoor Air Quality!
Resource.DescriptionText: List of facts regarding indoor airquality.
Resource.CommentsText: Easy to read factsheet. Provides a list of information regarding indoor air quality.

Resource.ResourceName: AWWA Online Free Learning Courses for Small Systems.
Resource.DescriptionText:
"FREE technical, financial and managerial training and assistance is available through a US Environmental Protection Agency Grant and AWWAÃƒÂ¢Ã‚Â€Ã‚Â™s training partners, the Rural Community Assistance Partnership (RCAP) and the Environmental Finance Center Network (EFCN). AWWA membership is not required, and in-person and online training is available through 2015. Training is designed to help small public water systems maintain compliance with the Safe Drinking Water Act (SDWA). Training includes online tutorials and in person assistance.
This eLearning course for financial sustainability focuses on 3 major areas needed by small systems to achieve financial sustainability; including understanding enterprise funds and their revenues, as well as an overview of what is needed to protect public health through safe water"

"Financial Sustainability for Small Systems (eLearning) - http://www.awwa.org/store/productdetail.aspx?productid=53117011

Resource.ResourceName: About the Office of Land and Emergency Management
Resource.DescriptionText: The Office of Land and Emergency Management provides policy, guidance and direction for the Agency's emergency response and waste programs. We develop guidelines for the land disposal of hazardous waste and underground storage tanks. We provide technical assistance to all levels of government to establish safe practices in waste management.
Resource.CommentsText: Basic Information about the office.

Resource.ResourceName: Access Climate Resources for Water Utilities
Resource.DescriptionText: A series of information, studies, and reports that are tailored specifically for water utilities. This resource provides water utilities with tools, training, and technical assistance needed to adapt to climate change. Some tools included are: Scenario planning to support decision making, CRWU 101 Introduction, Climate Change and Water Sector, Adaptation Strategies Guide, as well as various studies and reports.

Resource.ResourceName: Advanced Manufacturing Office: Office of Energy Efficiency & Renewable Energy
Resource.DescriptionText: Partner with industry, small business, universities, regional entities, and other stakeholders to identify and invest in emerging clean energy technologies. We establish collaborative communities focused on developing and commercializing targeted technologies; play a leadership role in the national interagency Advanced Manufacturing Partnership; and encourage a culture of continuous improvement in corporate energy management.
Resource.CommentsText: The Advanced Manufacturing Office (AMO) provides cost-shared funding to pursue innovative technology R&D and increase energy efficiency across the manufacturing sector.

Resource.ResourceName: Advanced Technology: Environmental and Energy Center
Resource.DescriptionText: A Resource for business, education, and government. Provides a series of materials, trainings, resources in regards to emerging environmental technologies.

Resource.ResourceName: Advancing Sustainable Materials Management: Facts and Figures
Resource.DescriptionText: Each year EPA produces a report called Advancing Sustainable Materials Management: Facts and Figures, formerly called Municipal Solid Waste in the United States: Facts and Figures. It includes information on municipal solid waste (MSW) generation, recycling, and disposal. The 2013 report provides additional information on source reduction (waste prevention) of MSW, information on historical tipping fees for MSW, and information on the Construction and Demolition Debris generation, which is outside of the scope of MSW.
Resource.CommentsText: Provides a list of facts and resources for advancing sustainable materials management.

Resource.DescriptionText: TheÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â Air DataÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â website gives you access to air quality data collected at outdoor monitors across the United States, Puerto Rico, and the U. S. Virgin Islands. The data comes primarily from the AQS (Air Quality System) database. You can choose from several ways of looking at the data.

To improve air quality, it is important for governments, industry and the public to understand the interconnected components of an air quality management system. This Web site describes each of these components and provides links to a tremendous amount of additional information, tools and resources provided on other EPA and non-EPA web sites.
Provides Air quality statistics and trends by state by year over a long period of time. This data can be used to generate reports or evaluate local air quality trends.

Resource.DescriptionText: These grants are provided to eligible entities, including nonprofit organizations, to develop environmental programs that recruit, train, and place unemployed and under-employed residents of communities affected by brownfields and other environmental contaminants with the skills needed to secure full-time, sustainable employment in the environmental field and in assessment and cleanup work taking place in their communities. Each Environmental Workforce Development and Job Training (EWDJT) grant may be funded up to $200,000 over a three year period.ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â

Resource.DescriptionText: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) created the Beach Advisory and Closing Online Notification (BEACON) system to meet the Agency's requirement to provide to the public a database of pollution occurrences for coastal recreation waters. EPA's response to this requirement, BEACON, contains state-reported beach monitoring and notification data. EPA recently updated BEACON to include several enhancements and has named the new system BEACON 2.0.
Resource.CommentsText: Provides an easy to use map where individuals may search the costal health of their beaches. Any spills or issues should be reported here on a fairly frequent basis.

Resource.ResourceName: Being Prepared for Climate Change Workbook for Developing Risk-Based Adaptations Plans
Resource.DescriptionText: TheÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â Being Prepared...ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â workbook andÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â the associated resources guide users to develop a risk-based climate change adaptation plan consisting of a vulnerability assessment and an action plan to reduce the most pressing risks. This Workbook presents a guide to climate change adaptation planning based on EPAÃƒÂ¢Ã‚Â€Ã‚Â™s experience with watershed management, the National Estuary Program and the Climate Ready Estuaries program. The Workbook will assist organizations that manage environmental resources to prepare a broad, risk-based adaptation plan.

An Educational Primer on Sustainable Water Infrastructure Asset Management. As interest in water and wastewater asset management among utilities has grown over the past decade, a number of professional and government organizations have attempted to define asset management and develop strategic plans in an effort to focus the practice and implementation of asset management. This site synthesizes these initiatives to develop an educational primer for water and wastewater utility infrastructure asset management.
Resource.CommentsText: Training tool that is not updated very often.

Resource.DescriptionText: The TAB program funds technical assistance to communities and other stakeholders on brownfields issues with the goal of increasing the community's understanding and involvement in brownfield cleanup and revitalization, and helping to move brownfields sites forward toward cleanup and reuse. The TAB grantees funded through the TAB program, among other things, serve as an independent resource assisting communities with community involvement, better understanding the health impacts of brownfield sites, science and technology relating to brownfield site assessment, remediation, and site preparation activities, brownfield finance questions, information on integrated approaches to brownfield cleanup and redevelopment, facilitating stakeholder involvement, identifying sources of brownfields assessment and cleanup funding, understanding and complying with state brownfields and voluntary cleanup program requirements, and facilitating redevelopment activities.

Resource.DescriptionText: In the final Clean Power Plan, the EPA provided a Clean Energy Incentive Program -- a program that states may use at their own option to incentivize early investments in wind and solar power generation, as well as in energy efficiency measures in low-income communities. State participation in the CEIP is optional; however, a state interested in participating in the CEIP must make a (non-binding) expression of its intent to participate in the CEIP in its plan or initial submittal due on September 6, 2016.
Resource.CommentsText: Program used to uincentivize early investments in wind and solar power.

Resource.ResourceName: Clean Power Plan For Existing Power Plants
Resource.DescriptionText: Shaped by years of unprecedented outreach and public engagement, the final Clean Power Plan is fair, flexible and designed to strengthen the fast-growing trend toward cleaner and lower-polluting American energy. With strong but achievable standards for power plants, and customized goals for states to cut the carbon pollution that is driving climate change, the Clean Power Plan provides national consistency, accountability and a level playing field while reflecting each stateÃƒÂ¢Ã‚Â€Ã‚Â™s energy mix.
Resource.CommentsText: Regulatory requirements.

Resource.ResourceName: Clean Power Plan State-Specific Fact Sheets
Resource.DescriptionText: State-specific fact sheets are provided below for 47 states (not including Alaska, Hawaii or Vermont). Each fact sheet includes the stateÃƒÂ¢Ã‚Â€Ã‚Â™s interim and final carbon dioxide emission performance goals (expressed in both rate and mass), and how the rate-based goals compare to proposed goals. The state goals are designed to be met as part of the grid and over time, reflecting the inherent flexibility in the way the power system operates and the variety of ways in which the electricity system can deliver a broad range of opportunities for compliance for power plants and states.
Resource.CommentsText: Help states to determine most cost-effective approach to reducing greenhouse gas emissions from the power sector.

Resource.ResourceName: Clean Water Act Laws, Regulations, Executive Orders
Resource.DescriptionText: The Clean Water Act (CWA) establishes the basic structure for regulating discharges of pollutants into the waters of the United States and regulating quality standards for surface waters. The basis of the CWA was enacted in 1948 and was called the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, but the Act was significantly reorganized and expanded in 1972. "Clean Water Act" became the Act's common name with amendments in 1972.
Resource.CommentsText: List of Laws and Regulations.

Resource.DescriptionText: Database that features over 530 Best Management Practices studies, performance analysis results, tools for use in BMP Performance studies, monitoring guidance, and other study related publications.

Resource.DescriptionText: The LT2ESWTR Microbial Toolbox - Version 2, updated in early 2007, is a Web tool that can help utilities meet requirements of the Long-Term 2 Enhanced Surface Water Treatment Rule by determining which treatment is most suitable for their water treatment plant. The Toolbox serves as a decision tree tool that will guide you through several steps to attain Cryptosporidium credits associated with the LT2ESWTR.
Resource.CommentsText: Provides an easy to follow wizard and guidance on the rule. Not updated often but still a good starting point. Would need to validated the data is accurate.

Resource.DescriptionText: Provides information on Landfills
Resource.CommentsText: Basic Information on Landfills.

Resource.ResourceName: Leak Detection and Repair: A Best Practices Guide
Resource.DescriptionText: Leaking equipment, such as valves, pumps, and connectors, are a large source of emissions of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and volatile hazardous air pollutants (VHAPs) The Leak Detection and Repair: A Best Practices GuideÃƒÂƒÃ‚Â‚ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â - is intended for use by regulated entities, such as petroleum refineries and chemical manufacturing facilities, as well as compliance inspectors. The guide details some of the problems identified with leak detection and repair (LDAR) programs. It focuses on Method 21 requirements, and describes the practices that can be used to increase the effectiveness of an LDAR program.
Resource.CommentsText: Beneficial tool for operators and managers.

Resource.DescriptionText: User reported waste around the world. Includes images and descriptions. Interactive map. Easy to use.

Resource.ResourceName: Microbial and Disinfection Byproducts (MDBP) Tools - LT2/Stage 2 Data Collection and Tracking System
Resource.DescriptionText: This page contains a tool for both the Long Term 2 Enhanced Surface Water Treatment Rule and the Stage 2 Disinfectants and Disinfection Byproducts Rule that can be used by public water systems and laboratories to submit required reports and monitoring data, including Grandfathered data. EPA developed the Information Processing and Management Center (IPMC) and Data Collection & Tracking System (DCTS) to help manage data submissions and notifications associated with implementation of the LT2 and Stage 2 DBP rules.
Resource.CommentsText: It can be accessed from the Compliance Main page. We might not want to include separate. Seems dated and is pretty much focused on submission of data vs any compliance help.

Resource.ResourceName: Microbial and Disinfection Byproducts (MDBP) Training Site
Resource.DescriptionText: This site is your one-stop for information about past and upcoming training for the implementation of the Stage 2, LT2 and Ground Water rules. On this site you will find information about Webcasts, train the trainer sessions, and other training opportunities designed to help you with the implementation of the Stage 2, LT2 and Ground Water rules as well as the older rules if applicable to you.
Resource.CommentsText: It can be accessed from the Compliance Main page. We might not want to include separate. Provides free training on the rule. If listserv available these could be published to state or local sites.

Resource.DescriptionText: New technologies are changing the way we monitor pollution in the environment. EPA is studying innovative technologies that will measure nutrient pollution in the air and water

Resource.ResourceName: Municipalities and Wastewater Treatment Plants Basics
Resource.DescriptionText: "Municipal staff, who are responsible for meeting NPDES permit obligations, must understand how the NPDES permit program works, who should be involved and educated about the NPDES program, and what information is available to help perform their jobs effectively. The website provides links and information to resources and tools available to municipal wastewater managers in meeting EPA regulations "
Resource.CommentsText: Website provides reference to EPA's Wastewater Regs relevant to wastewater operators and gives a starting point. If additional information is needed we could pull out specific regs and link to them. This data could be put into a decision tree similar.

Resource.DescriptionText: MyWATERS Mapper dynamically displays snapshots of EPA Office of Water program data. This version of MyWATERS Mapper depicts the status of NPDES permits for each State; summary information from the Clean Watershed Needs Survey; and water quality assessments. Future versions will include other Office of Water Program Snapshots. MyWATERS Mapper also contains water-related geographic themes such as 12-digit watersheds, the national stream network known as the National Hydrography Dataset, and other water-related map layers. MyWATERS Mapper enables you to create customized maps at national and local scales.
Resource.CommentsText: Requires shockwave in order to operate.

Resource.DescriptionText: Various application forms that are applicable to a number of NPDES program areas.
Resource.CommentsText: Forms required for NPDES permitting.

Resource.DescriptionText: FAQ for NPDES with a series of topics: Permitting, TMDL, Water Quality based Permit Limits for Recreational Water Quality Data
Resource.CommentsText: Basic FAQ regarding NDPES.

Resource.DescriptionText: Contains basic information on the major features and elements of the NPDES permit program. The information in this section will be most useful to state and tribal officials, interested citizens, and others with an interest in the details of the NPDES program. This information is broadly applicable to all NPDES permits and programs, including concentrated animal feeding operations (CAFOs), pesticide discharges, combined sewer overflows (CSOs), pretreatment, sanitary sewer overflows (SSOs), stormwater and whole effluent toxicity (WET).
Resource.CommentsText: Website provides reference to all of EPA's Wastewater Regs and gives a starting point. If additional information is needed we could pull out specific regs and link to them. This would relevant to stormwater as well.

Resource.DescriptionText: The NPDES permitting program offers training courses, workshops, and webinars to explain the regulatory framework and technical considerations of the NPDES permit program. Resource.ResourceName: National Air Quality Site Assessment Tool
Resource.DescriptionText: The National Air Quality Site Assessment Tool (NAQSAT) has been developed for the voluntary use of livestock producers and their advisors or consultants. It is intended to provide assistance to livestock and poultry producers in determining the areas in their operations where there are opportunities to make changes that result in reduced air emissions. Air emissions research from livestock production systems is increasing every year. NAQSAT is based on the most accurate, credible data currently available regarding mitigation strategies for air emissions of ammonia, methane, volatile organic compounds, hydrogen sulfide, particulates, and odor.
Resource.CommentsText: Will be valuable for specific rural communities.

Resource.ResourceName: National Emissions Inventory (NEI) Air Pollutant Emission Trends Data
Resource.DescriptionText: Current emissions trends data and the documentation of estimation methods are available, or linked here. The latest version of data 1970-2014 data shows trends for Tier 1 categories. Information about the NEI is available on the NEI webpage. One of the distinct natural occurrences in inventory development is the evolution and improvement of emission estimate methods over time. Any changes to data or methodologies used to estimate emissions for a specific time period will continue to be noted.

Resource.ResourceName: National Environmental Services Center Drinking Water and Wastewater Financial Assistance, Tools, Database and Technical Assistance
Resource.DescriptionText: For over 35 years, the National Environmental Services Center (NESC) has helped thousands of small, rural communities with their drinking water, wastewater, environmental training, infrastructure resilience, and utility management needs--leading them to solutions to the problems they face. The site includes technical assistance phone numbers and ask the experts email and phone number. In addition it includes 2 listservs for drinking and wastewater. The site has migrated to Facebook and can be found at https://www.facebook.com/NationalEnvironmentalServicesCenter
Resource.CommentsText: This is a large website that provides numerous resources. The site has most recently moved to updating via Facebook. Much of the site material is outdated and they are most focused on technical assistance vs tool development.

Resource.ResourceName: National Oil and Hazardous Substance Contingency Plan (NCP) Overview.
Resource.DescriptionText: The National Oil and Hazardous Substances Pollution Contingency Plan, more commonly called the National Contingency Plan or NCP, is the federal government's blueprint for responding to both oil spills and hazardous substance releases. The NCP is the result of efforts to develop a national response capability and promote coordination among the hierarchy of responders and contingency plans.
Resource.CommentsText: Overview discussing spills and information.

Resource.DescriptionText: The National Response System (NRS) routinely and effectively responds to a wide range of oil and hazardous substance releases. It is a multi-layered system of individuals and teams from local, state, and federal agencies, industry, and other organizations. These groups share expertise and resources to ensure that cleanup activities are timely, efficient, and minimize threats to human health and the environment.
Resource.CommentsText: Recommended in times of emergency.

Resource.DescriptionText: Resource that provides information on a variety different types of disasters that may occur. Drought, earthquakes, heat, floods, hurricanes, landslides, and weather.
Resource.CommentsText: Basic information depending on the type of natural disaster. Informs users of what to expect and how to prepare.

Resource.DescriptionText: Traditionally, air pollution is measured by expensive, stationary and complex air-monitoring instrumentation. Only a few organizations, like federal, state and some industries, typically collect data of such high quality. Even so, this limits the amount of environmental monitoring data that is often available for exposure and health assessments. As air quality management problems become more complex, there is a need for enhanced air quality and exposure monitoring capabilities.
Resource.CommentsText: Informational, EPA, Education

The Partnership for Sustainable Communities (PSC) works to coordinate federal housing, transportation, water, and other infrastructure investments to make neighborhoods more prosperous, allow people to live closer to jobs, save households time and money, and reduce pollution. The partnership agencies incorporate six principles of livability into federal funding programs, policies, and future legislative proposals. - See more at: https://www.sustainablecommunities.gov/mission/about-us#sthash.QmG60WC3.dpuf"

The Center is working to: ÃƒÂ¢Ã‚Â€Ã‚Â¢Promote innovative financing approaches. Resource.PrimaryOrganizationText: EPA / OLEM - Office of Land and Emergency Management
Resource.DescriptionText:
See how much enegy is saved when you recycle an item, and the common household item that energy can power.
Add the iWARM widget to your Web page. The widget helps users on your Web site understand how much energy is saved through recycling, and lets them share their results. The iWARM widget displays energy-saving benefits of recycling. This is the widget-version of the iWARM, which helps consumers understand the energy saved by recycling small quantities of common household products, rather than landfilling them. The energy savings are translated into the equivalent amount of electricity, estimating how long that amount of electricity will operate a variety of household appliances.
Resource.CommentsText:
The iWARM widget displays energy-saving benefits of recycling. This is the widget-version of the iWARM, which helps consumers understand the energy saved by recycling small quantities of common household products, rather than landfilling them. The energy savings are translated into the equivalent amount of electricity, estimating how long that amount of electricity will operate a variety of household appliances.
The energy calculations are based on the Waste Reduction Model (WARM), which was created to help solid waste planners and organizations track greenhouse gas emissions reductions from several different waste management practices. For information on the data and methodologies behind the calculations, please see the model documentation.
You can share your calculation results on Twitter or Facebook, or embed the widget on your own website. There are two variations of the widget that are available for use. The widget can be added to a variety of web pages. If you need help in adding a widget to your Web page, please contact your webmaster or service provider.
Easy to use widget that can be downloaded to use in Excel or added to a webpage. The code is provided.
